articles.headline: Design Helps H.P. Profit More on PCs
articles.snippet: Hewlett-Packard’s effort to transform its personal computers into more stylish devices has started to pay off.
articles.abstract: Hewlett-Packard’s effort to transform its personal computers into more stylish devices has started to pay off.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, May 16  Hewlett-Packard’s effort to transform its personal computers from low-margin commodities into more stylish devices has started to pay off.

articles.headline: In Bid for Better Care, Surgery With a Warranty
articles.snippet: A hospital group is trying a radically new method to avoid costly mistakes, charging a flat fee that includes follow-up care.
articles.abstract: A hospital group is trying a radically new method to avoid costly mistakes, charging a flat fee that includes follow-up care.
articles.lead_paragraph: What if medical care came with a 90-day warranty?

articles.headline: Chrysler Sale Unavoidable, Chief Says
articles.snippet: The chief executive of DaimlerChrysler argued that Cerberus offers the “best possible future setup” for his company.
articles.abstract: The chief executive of DaimlerChrysler argued that Cerberus offers the “best possible future setup” for his company.
articles.lead_paragraph: STUTTGART, Germany, May 16  On Monday evening at Chrysler’s offices in Auburn Hills, Mich., Dieter Zetsche held what is likely to be his last, and most poignant, session of “Ask Dr. Z.”

articles.headline: Amazon to Sell Music Without Copy Protection
articles.snippet: The online store, to be introduced later this year, will allow people to play music on almost any personal device.
articles.abstract: The online store, to be introduced later this year, will allow people to play music on almost any personal device.
articles.lead_paragraph: Amazon.com, the biggest online seller of CDs, is joining the movement against copy-protection software for digital music. It plans to sell songs that can be freely copied to any computer, cellphone or music player, including the iPod from Apple.
articles.byline: By Brad Stone and Jeff Leeds

articles.headline: Paying More for a Printer, but Less for Ink
articles.snippet: It’s war in the world of inkjet printers and cartridges as Kodak gets into the business.
articles.abstract: It’s war in the world of inkjet printers and cartridges as Kodak gets into the business.
articles.lead_paragraph: In some ways, the world of electronics is a great big game of Us vs. Them, filled with imbalances of power that the little people can’t do anything about. Through learned helplessness, we’ve come to accept that the gadget we buy today will be passé in a year — period. Calling technical support is going to be a nightmare — tough rocks. Buying cartridges for an inkjet printer will cost twice as much as the printer itself — each year.

articles.headline: For ’08 Résumés, Don’t Ask Them to Fill in Blanks
articles.snippet: The current crop of presidential candidates has taken to eliminating whole chapters of their histories.
articles.abstract: The current crop of presidential candidates has taken to eliminating whole chapters of their histories.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 16 — Stealing a page from the Soviet playbook, the current crop of presidential candidates has taken to eliminating whole chapters of their histories.

articles.headline: Unity Fractures as Palestinians Battle in Gaza
articles.snippet: At least 19 Palestinians were killed in fighting between Fatah and Hamas as rage rises on both sides.
articles.abstract: At least 19 Palestinians were killed in fighting between Fatah and Hamas as rage rises on both sides.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM, May 16 — Gaza City was shuttered on Wednesday as gunmen took over rooftops and top-floor apartments. Most everyone else huddled fearfully indoors on the fourth day of factional Palestinian fighting that is drawing in the Israeli military.

articles.headline: Parallel Paths Diverging Sharply
articles.snippet: As Conrad Black tries to avoid prison, Marie-Josée Kravis, his  longtime ally, floats atop New York society.
articles.abstract: As Conrad Black tries to avoid prison, Marie-Josée Kravis, his  longtime ally, floats atop New York society.
articles.lead_paragraph: On a hot evening this week in the Museum of Modern Art’s garden, Marie-Josée Kravis, the museum president, and her husband, Henry, played host to more than 900 guests who mingled near two giant Richard Serra sculptures. Her presence was cool and reserved, and her outfit of a shimmering sequin top and dark slacks struck a conservative tone amid the sun-fired skin and tummy-hugging gowns that the wives of other moguls favored.
